instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00850: What is 820-00850? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V3_G3H: What is PP3V3_G3H? PP3V3_G3H is a 3.3v power line that is present when the machine is in a Global System Hardware Off state, and should come on before most other rails so that the USB-C circuitry can be powered for the charger.
definitions.PPDCIN_G3H: What is PPDCIN_G3H? PPDCIN_G3H Is a power rail that comes directly from the laptop charger..
definitions.PP5V_G3S: What is PP5V_G3S? PP5V_G3S is a 5v power rail present when the system is in a G3S standby state.
definitions.PPVCC_S0_CPU: What is PPVCC_S0_CPU? The "PPVCC_S0_CPU" power rail is responsible for supplying power to the CPU when the MacBook is fully on, or in the S0 state. This rail is one of the main voltages that the CPU requires for operation. .
definitions.PPVCCIO_S0_CPU: What is PPVCCIO_S0_CPU? PPVCCIO_S0_CPU is a power rail responsible for powering the part of the CPU responsible for communicating with other portions of the machine prior to PPVCORE_S0_CPU being present and must be present before vcore, PPVCCIO_S0_CPU is present when the machine is in an on, RUNNING state. .
definitions.PP1V8_S5: What is PP1V8_S5? PP1V8_S5 is a 1.8v power rail present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no display on internal or external screen
threads.message:
Hi again.
I get 20 volts to F3001 when connected to the outer USBC port on J3300.

The trackpad clicks, so the unit is turning on, but there is no display.
The power button will turn the unit on and off - i.e. the clicking will stop, or start, again.

There is no signs of any liquid ingress to either side of the logic board.

I've tried with an external monitor with the internal screen disconnected, using a known-good USBC-HDMI adapter.
I've also tried with a known-good panel.

Not familiar with this board.
Any help appreciated as to where to start this one.

<SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H</SIGNAL> = 20.30v
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> = 12.57v
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> = 3.36v
<SIGNAL>PP5V_G3S</SIGNAL> = 5.14v

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no display on internal or external screen
threads.message:
Trackpad click is not life sign on new machines.
Remember to check for USB activity; is the best way to confirm if board really boots.
Check at least CPU core voltage; should drop after 10-15s to aprox 0.6V.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no display on internal or external screen
threads.message:
Ah, OK.
I had assumed that the trackpad click was a sign of life on all of them.
Plus the fact the power button would seem to turn the trackpad on and off.

However, no signs of life from any USBC port with a USB with a LED on it.

<SIGNAL>PPVCC_S0_CPU</SIGNAL> = 0v

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_HS_CPU</SIGNAL> = 12.56v
<SIGNAL>PPVPCORE_S5</SIGNAL> = 0v
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_S5</SIGNAL> = 0v
<SIGNAL>PPVCCGT_S0_CPU</SIGNAL> = 0v
<SIGNAL>PPVCCIO_S0_CPU</SIGNAL> =0v

I guess dead?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no display on internal or external screen
threads.message:
You've wasted time testing with abother panel, when your machine doesn't even get S5 voltages.
Until S0 is long way...

Try DFU revive.
